text: So, how would you say they want to visit and the people wanting to visit are an entirely male group?
Ils veulent visiter.
Now try it with an entirely female group.
Elles veulent visiter.
Finally, we now have a mixed group. How would you say they want to visit?
Ils veulent visiter.
As you can see with a mixed group, it simply reverts to ils.
So, again with an all male group, how would you say they want to reserve?
Ils veulent réserver.
They want to camp.
Ils veulent camper.
They want to camp here.
Ils veulent camper ici.
They want to camp there.
Ils veulent camper là.
They want to camp over there.
Ils veulent camper là-bas.
So, as you can see, some of these verbs really are very familiar to English speakers.
We have visit, which is of course...
Visiter.
To reserve, which is of course...
Réserver.
To camp, which is...
Camper.
And there's a whole group of verbs like this, simply with an ER added on the end.
For instance, how would you say to stay, which in French is of course to rest?
How would you say to pay?
To pay.
Payé.
In that case, what do you think to desire would be?
Désirer.
Désirer.
Pronunciation is very slightly different, and you'll find that in French occasionally.
But it's not so difficult to remember because it is quite familiar.
So, again, if to desire is...
Désirer.
How would you say you desire?
Vous désirez.
As you can see, the desire when used with the you with the vous form, it sounds simply like
to desire.
There is a slight spelling difference.
At the end of desire, when it's you desire, there is a Z.
Whereas with to desire, there is an R.
However, in speaking, it sounds exactly the same.
So, for spoken French, it's not something you particularly need to worry about.
So, one more time.
How would you say you desire?
Vous désirez.
Now, let's turn that into a question and say you desire.
Vous désirez.
This is a very common way for a waiter or someone at a restaurant to ask you what it is you want
to drink or to eat.
They'll simply say you desire.
It's very common in French and something that's worth getting used to.
You can, of course, turn it round and actually say desire you.
How would you say that?
Desire you?
Désirez-vous?
How would you say desire you to take a coffee?
Désirez-vous prendre un café?
This is the normal way that a waiter, when being very polite, will ask you that sort of question.
Note that the French will use prendre, to take, rather than say to have.
They will not use have in this situation.
So, what do you want to have or what do you want to take?
In English, perhaps, particularly in the past, one spoke about taking a drink or something
like that, but it's not really used now.
However, in French, it's very normal and very typical language.
All right.
Now, if someone asks you that, of course, you're going to need to give them an answer.
How would you say, yes, two coffees?
Oui, deux cafés.
Of course, you may well get this at the end of a meal, at which time you'll probably also
ask for the bill.
The bill in French is literally the addition, which in French is pronounced as l'addition.
Now, you can hear on that the word for the, which is an L. Normally, you'll have a LE or
a LA.
However, if it's followed by a word beginning with a vowel, the French will abbreviate it
and they'll write L' and then addition in this case, which instead of making it sound like
addition, it sounds like the bill, which is l'addition.
But there are actually two separate words there, but merged into one.
And you'll get very used to the fact that the French use a lot of abbreviations and merge
words together.
So again, what would the bill be?
L'addition.
So how would you say, yes, two coffees and the bill, please?
Oui, deux cafés et l'addition, s'il vous plaît.
Did you remember how to say please?
Again, the literal meaning of please in French is if it pleases you, which again is s'il vous
plaît.
You can hear the vous in there, the you, and the play at the end means pleases.
So it's literally if it pleases you.
It sounds a bit old-fashioned and courtly in English, but it's very normal in French.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
